title: Do you still use an iPhone 4? - Quora

response.answer_text: Do you still use an iPhone 4? Thanks for your request to answer. But, fortunately for me. I have never owned an iPhone device. I am an Android person… yes, think whatever you wish, but I don’t like Apple’s iPhones. I don’t like it not because it is a bad product, on the contrary, it is a beautifully designed product with an excellent operating system (*NIX related, same as Android *NIX -Linux actually- based kernel), so, no engineering-wise complaints. I dislike iPhones because of Apple’s policy and attitude of limiting users in everything and anything. They love controlling what you can do or not do with and to your smartphone, you hard earned smartphone. I am not like that, so I prefer Android. As of security, lots of people ask me about this, believing Apple is “far more secure”; I don’t agree: security, device’s security is a state at any give moment. It is not a constant situation: One second you are 100% secure, the next second you are absolutely hacked and cracked and your identity stolen. Apple,as well, as Android and others…are not innocent in this regard, not any of them. All single one platform has had its breaches of security and some companies have even tried to hide the situation to their users and customers…that’s your homework for you: to find out who has done that. So, there you go… I have never owned an iPhone (someone at my home has owned Apple devices) and I have no plans on getting one, not now and not in the near future. But, thanks for the question anyway.

Yes, it makes a great music player.. I can still load MP3s onto it and the sound quality from the 3.5mm headphone jack is actually surprisingly very good for an phone that was from 2010. Unfortunately Apple made the phone pretty much obsolete because I cannot install or update new apps.. only a very few apps can be downloaded from the App Store and the phone pretty much is useless without apps. TuneIn radio and YouTube surprisingly still works, though they are running an older version of the app (UPDATE: the YouTube app has been DISCONTINUED on the iPhone 4 and 4s… very unfortunate.. you could still access YouTube from a web browser though). I use the phone mostly for music and keep airplane mode on to save battery, only using WiFi if I need to stream music from the two apps above. The headphone jack is great and I don't understand why people aren't mad at Apple for removing it.. I have it connected to speakers and it constantly plays music, nature sounds, or internet radio streaming everyday. I don't use it as a phone of course and the web browser is very outdated and slow, so it's only used for music and maybe as an alarm clock. Shame on Apple for making the phone obsolete by not allowing apps to be installed or updated, there are many apps that I cannot install. This was actually the last phone by Steve Jobs and I really enjoy the physical design of it.. the screen is flat, it has a headphone jack, and the side bezels are made from stainless steel.. plus, the screen is completely flat so installing screen protectors are easy.

Hi, Thanks for your question. iPhone is in line of the most premium smartphones in the world. Especially where I come from Africa Kenya, owning an iPhone is considered as if you are rich or a big spender. I have used iPhone 6, 6+,6s and 7. Back to your question, about iPhone 4; yes people still use the device. Despite it being a very old iPhone in the market. I have assisted so many customers who were using iPhone 4 and they were okay with how it’s performing. WhatsApp and Gmail announced that their application will no longer be supported in iPhone 4. All iOS applications available from the Apple Store can’t be supported in an iPhone 4 so no access to social media and you can’t install your favorite applications. Inbuilt apps still work well but not as fast as you would experience while using the latter models. Whenever I assist a customer using iPhone 4, it's always an opportunity to upgrade them to the latest model which they later come and purchase. So to answer your question; yes they work but only for calling and texting hence not a suitable Apple device to own when the Company has advanced their later products with better features and giving all customers the reason to upgrade. Personally, the iPhone 4 doesn’t allow the user to enjoy the privilege of using an Apple device so I won’t call it an iPhone anymore.

No, not as a regular phone that I carry with me. But, i do have one that i use occasionally for music or imessage if my main phone is dead. However, I do recommend an IPhone 4 for older people, because its very simple. But its very very outdated and runs on IOS 7 or 8, so you can’t download mostly any app in the app store. Its also very slow and doing a quick google search is a hassle. If your looking for a cheap IPhone to get I recommend the IPhone 6, IPhone 6S, or the old IPhone SE. Now, if your looking for a simple phone that is easy to use and wont be used for much, than I recommend the IPhone 5.

I used my iPhone 4 up until last year when I recycled it for a couple of bucks. It worked great for several years when I first got it in about 2013. I replaced the battery in about 2015 because it would die after a few hours. Unfortunately, Apple doesn’t support iPhones below the 6s so it is currently stuck on an outdated iOS from 2013. Up until I recycled it, I used it to listen to music in my car. I could always have it plugged in charging and I would hook it up via headphone jack and use it like an mp3 player. Worked great in the summer but unfortunately the battery would actually discharge in the winter even when plugged into power because it was so cold outside.

Though it hasn’t been on a phone network for years, I just stopped using an iPhone 4 as a dedicated music player permanently set in a 30-pin dock, replacing it with a iPhone 4S. iOS 7.1.2 successfully ran an old version of Audible, Amazon Music, Google Play, Overdrive, and even an old version of my home automation software. Unfortunately, I started using Libby to listen to audiobooks from my library, and the App Store effectively played a sad trombone when I tried to install it. The iPhone 4S runs the still-obsolete 9.3.6, but that supports a lot more apps and newer versions than those on the iPhone 4. Anyone want an 8GB Verizon iPhone 4, cheap?

There are a number of people that do. I’m addicted with my iPhone 5c, although its always out of available space. All of the “older” versions of the iPhone (4, 4s, 5, 5c) tend to be really slower - not to say slugish at times, if you run out of space too - compared to their next generation siblings, but still quite usable. If you’re considering to upgrade to a newer version it’s probably worth thinking of repurposing your iPhone. One thought that has come accross my mind is making it a baby monitor and believe me if you run a search on google you’ll get endless ideas.

I actually used an iPhone 4 up until about a year ago. The reason that I finally got rid of it was because the apps began to break down and not function correctly. I was no longer able to add contacts, the weather app stayed frozen and wouldn’t update, Gas Buddy stopped working, among other things. I will always love the design and form factor of the iPhone 4, it feels just right in your hand. It wasn’t easy to let it go, I have to admit. It was a great smartphone before the phablets took over.

Actually I never had any of the 4/4S phones. I didn’t have any money to upgrade and my 3GS was a perfect device for me. It survived many falls, fit my hand perfectly, fit in my pocket or purse, had great battery life and did everything I wanted it to do. I didn’t upgrade until I started working at AT&T, servicing iPhone customers. And now new phone envy grabs me every year.

Personally - no, as it is slow, probably old (which causes old battery and replacement accessories issues) and probably might die at some unexpected point. At the same time I know a few people (safe to say ‘old’), that use it (sometimes as one of their devices, not the only one. They don’t need new cutting-edge tech, they don’t need big display, they only use it to call, send messages and occasionally make photos, end of story. And they admire iOS’s reliability.

Yes, but I develop iPhone apps, so I use it for testing. It’s my oldest phone I can support at the moment, but I have working models back to the original, 3g, 3GS etc. Realistically, it’s a fine phone, but modern Apps don’t target it. So you’re stuck in the past. But as a phone it still works. Your data speeds are in the past too. But it’s usable. Certainly makes a good backup if you keep an adapter around for the sim.

Yep. While I’m currently using a much newer iPhone SE as my regular smartphone, my iPhone 4 is in daily use as a dash camera in my car. Works great! My wife’s old iPhone 4 (that was also replaced with an iPhone SE recently) is also in daily use by a family member in another country. It was a big improvement over the iPhone 3G it replaced for them. They love it.

Yes I still do.I got mine back in 2011 and it is a 32 GB model.I have many offline games on it and many apps like Netflix and Spotify still work well on it.Youtube recently stopped working recently but it still works perfectly on a browser.I don’t use it as a main phone but it can still run plenty of apps and is fairly usable.The only problem I have with it is that it does not support 4G and mobile data speed is very low on 3G.

Who me? You ever saw me using one? I don't use any Apple products as of now! I'm an Android Guy so I really don't like Apple's policy of not giving users a complete freedom of what to do in iOS! But I believe there are still people who use iPhone 4 even now in 2020, my friend used to have one in 2019, not sure if he changed after that…

Thanks for the A2A! This one is no longer my main device, but I still use it from time to time as an iPod touch for my iTunes music, movies and Spotify looping/shuffling. And some good memories I have in it’s camera roll! P.S.: one of my friend who is anti-tech still uses one as a main device for calls/texts, iMessage, and taking photos.

A 4S is my primary phone, and also the one I'm writing on right now. With iOS 9 it's quite slow but still usable. A 3GS with iOS 6 is my secondary phone. It's not very compatible with modern web or situations, but still gets the job done and it's FAST. A huge problem with the 4 (not S) is iOS 7, wich was really too heavy for that phone. If you can keep iOS 6 on it it wouldn't be bad at all.

Me No! My girlfriend does and it’s a step up from her flip phone. Anything below a 4S is way out-dated and too slow for me. iPhone 7Plus and Samsung P70 are my current medium but I find the P70 general software is slow reacting to my selections and starting. It is very fast in accessing the internet so it’s hard to say which is better but the iPhone 4 sucks 5 years ago or more.

No. I do however use an iPhone 6 Plus daily as a pimped up iPod. 128gb memory, access to Apple Music and compatible with AirPods Pro. I felt the resell value of roughly £100 was not as much value as keeping it for this dedicated use. I hardly ever use my iPhone 11 Pro Max for music or audio.

Well, I have never used an iPhone 4, like, long-term, so no.I don’t even like iPhones that much. I saved up money for an iPhone SE few years ago coming from Android, and the lack of the file manager like Windows and Android was a big pain for me.Now I am daily-driving a Xiaomi Pocophone F1.

Hi. Thanks for your query about iPhone 4. Now, for me, I am using iPhone 7+. I also checked this item. From the data, a couple of people are still using iPhone 4. Oh, if you want to buy this one. I think that is not a clever choice. Now the newest iOS 14 are coming soon. It only supports iPhone 6s or later. iPhone 11 or above will be a good choice after iPhone 12.

No. I used to have an iPhone 4s back in 2016 though and i liked it. I prefer iOS over android but it is a pain in the ass to put music on an iPhone for free. I'm not paying for music I already own (physical format) the whole process is annoying and takes a lot of time. But no I don't use an iPhone 4

No, i don’t use an iPhone 4 these days because it’s very obsolete and wouldn’t not be capable for using standard applications on it. Also the battery life on the iPhone 4 will not last you long during the day. If you still have one I strongly suggest you just upgrade to a newer or newest iPhone.

Well, I’m still using the iPhone 4 as a music player/iPod. Battery life isn’t that great, but apart from that it is still working as a music player. If I get the battery replaced, then I believe it will work for another 3–4 years. I still feel that iPhone 4 and 4S are the most durable/reliable iPhones ever produced by Apple.

I used to own one back in 2011. I don’t use it and don’t own it anymore. If someone tried using the 4 it would be very outdated and slow. I don’t recommend it to anyone. If you’re looking for a iPhone get a 6S and up.

No. The iPhone 4 no longer is supported by Apple which means that it will not get any software updates. In theory we could use the iPhone 4 because it is still 4g and is still supported by some carriers but I would not recommend it for myself or any others.

Some apps, yes, but most modern apps require a newer version of iOS to be downloaded. If a developer has been around for many years there may still be older versions of the app that are available for download (it will prompt you to download an older version when you hit download if this is available).
No one does only thing apple is taking care of is the 6s series and newer the old stuff is dead like all old phones and iPhones from the 6 series and back dead only 6s and newer

i used before know using iphone 5 its little better and dosent hang much but storage is low if your searching for a mobile with nice and market prices in it then i recommint you to visit OKK MOBILE its new site and the prices and specification are very much up to date search there iphone x its new and good mobile
No! It does not support the latest ios version after ios7. Though its an amazing phone but its already obsolete from the market.

Thanks for the A2A. It depends on what you mean by “supported.” If you mean can you get technical support on apps on the iPhone 4, it depends on the app’s developer. Some will offer it and some won’t. If you are talking new apps, no. New apps need to work with the most recent version of iOS and are almost always not backwards compatible with iPhones that run older versions of iOS which Apple is no longer supporting.
No. Currently i use iPhone . But i have seen many people with iPhone 4
Do you still use and iPhone 4?
Nope. I use a 6S
No.
No.
No
No
